title: System shock
data:
**System shock** is the generic term for the effects which cause destruction when using [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") magic (including [polymorphitis](/wiki/Polymorphitis "Polymorphitis")). Different effects happen to objects, monsters, and the player. In all three cases, the associated message is some variation on "shuddering." In real world terms this is perhaps better described as a massive trauma.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Objects](#Objects)
- [2 Monsters](#Monsters)
- [3 Player](#Player)
- [4 Messages](#Messages)
- [5 References](#References)

## Objects

[Objects](/wiki/Object "Object") have a chance of shuddering depending on type and [beatitude](/wiki/Beatitude "Beatitude"). A [wand](/wiki/Wand "Wand") or [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") object has a 1⁄3 (guaranteed for stacks of more than 4) of shuddering. An [uncursed](/wiki/Uncursed "Uncursed") non-wand object has a 1⁄8 chance of shuddering. For a [blessed](/wiki/Blessed "Blessed") object the chance is 1⁄12. The chance is doubled if the object stack is larger than 4 objects.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

When an object shudders, randomly up to all but one, or one if there was only one object, is destroyed.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) For each object in the original stack, there is a 1 in (45 + [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck")) chance of a [golem](/wiki/Golem "Golem") being created. The golem type depends on the material of the original objects: glass objects make a glass golem, cloth objects make a rope golem, bone objects create a skeleton, etc. If the golem or skeleton is genocided, a random monster is created instead.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) Only one golem (or other monster) can be created per square affected by polymorph.

If a golem (or other monster) is created, then after all appropriate objects on the square have been polymorphed, and some were destroyed by system shock, more objects on this square are destroyed. If the monster weight is W, at most W objects can be destroyed. The game looks at each object, or stack of objects, in order from the top of the pile, and deletes it if it is of the same material as the object which shuddered to create the golem. (However, with 1/(W+1) chance, the object or stack will only be deleted if it is *not* of the same material.)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

The [unique items](/wiki/Unique_item "Unique item"), [rider](/wiki/Rider "Rider") corpses, and [scrolls of mail](/wiki/Scrolls_of_mail "Scrolls of mail") never cause system shock,[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7) and are protected from destruction if another object caused it.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)

## Monsters

[Monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster") have a 1⁄25 chance of dying without leaving a [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") when hit by a [wand of polymorph](/wiki/Wand_of_polymorph "Wand of polymorph"), [polymorph spell](/wiki/Spellbook_of_polymorph "Spellbook of polymorph"), or [potion of polymorph](/wiki/Potion_of_polymorph "Potion of polymorph"). The test is done after the tests for magic resistance. [Chameleons](/wiki/Chameleon "Chameleon"), [doppelgangers](/wiki/Doppelganger "Doppelganger"), and [sandestins](/wiki/Sandestin "Sandestin") are immune, unless the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") has [protection from shape changers](/wiki/Ring_of_protection_from_shape_changers "Ring of protection from shape changers").[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)

## Player

The [player](/wiki/Player "Player") is not subject to instant destruction like the other classes of polymorphable things. Instead, when you polymorph randomly, you have a 19 − [Con](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution")19 chance of experiencing a system shock. If this happens, you lose 1d30 [hit points](/wiki/Hit_points "Hit points") and [abuse](/wiki/Abuse "Abuse") your constitution. This effect will not occur if you have [polymorph control](/wiki/Ring_of_polymorph_control "Ring of polymorph control"), have [lycanthropy](/wiki/Lycanthropy "Lycanthropy"), are a [vampire](/wiki/Vampire "Vampire") or [vampire bat](/wiki/Vampire_bat "Vampire bat"), or wear [dragon scale mail or dragon scales](/wiki/Dragon_scale_mail "Dragon scale mail").[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

## Messages

- You feel shuddering vibrations.

  A polymorphed object has undergone system shock.

- The \<monster> shudders.

  A polymorphed monster has undergone system shock.

- [You shudder for a moment](/wiki/You_shudder_for_a_moment "You shudder for a moment").

  One of the possible sources of this message is that you have undergone system shock.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [obj\_shudders](/wiki/Source:Zap.c#obj_shudders "Source:Zap.c") in [zap.c](/wiki/Source:Zap.c "Source:Zap.c")
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [zap.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1353](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.1_Release/zap.c#L1353)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [create\_polymon](/wiki/Source:Zap.c#create_polymon "Source:Zap.c") in [zap.c](/wiki/Source:Zap.c "Source:Zap.c")
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [polyuse](/wiki/Source:Zap.c#polyuse "Source:Zap.c") in [zap.c](/wiki/Source:Zap.c "Source:Zap.c")
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [zap.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1854](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.1_Release/zap.c#L1854)
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [zap.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1338](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.1_Release/zap.c#L1338)
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [obj\_resists](/wiki/Source:Zap.c#obj_resists "Source:Zap.c") in [zap.c](/wiki/Source:Zap.c "Source:Zap.c")
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [zap.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1209](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.1_Release/zap.c#L1209)
9. [↑](#cite_ref-9) [src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 251](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/zap.c#L251)
10. [↑](#cite_ref-10) [polyself](/wiki/Source:Polyself.c#polyself "Source:Polyself.c") in [polyself.c](/wiki/Source:Polyself.c "Source:Polyself.c")

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.1. Click here for more information.](/images/d/d3/Nh361-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.1. Click here for more information.")

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1"). Information on this page may be out of date.

html:
System shock

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

System shock is the generic term for the effects which cause destruction when using polymorph magic (including polymorphitis). Different effects happen to objects, monsters, and the player. In all three cases, the associated message is some variation on "shuddering." In real world terms this is perhaps better described as a massive trauma.

Contents

  • 1 Objects
  • 2 Monsters
  • 3 Player
  • 4 Messages
  • 5 References

Objects

Objects have a chance of shuddering depending on type and beatitude. A wand or cursed object has a 1⁄3 (guaranteed for stacks of more than 4) of shuddering. An uncursed non-wand object has a 1⁄8 chance of shuddering. For a blessed object the chance is 1⁄12. The chance is doubled if the object stack is larger than 4 objects.[1]

When an object shudders, randomly up to all but one, or one if there was only one object, is destroyed.[2] For each object in the original stack, there is a 1 in (45 + Luck) chance of a golem being created. The golem type depends on the material of the original objects: glass objects make a glass golem, cloth objects make a rope golem, bone objects create a skeleton, etc. If the golem or skeleton is genocided, a random monster is created instead.[3] Only one golem (or other monster) can be created per square affected by polymorph.

If a golem (or other monster) is created, then after all appropriate objects on the square have been polymorphed, and some were destroyed by system shock, more objects on this square are destroyed. If the monster weight is W, at most W objects can be destroyed. The game looks at each object, or stack of objects, in order from the top of the pile, and deletes it if it is of the same material as the object which shuddered to create the golem. (However, with 1/(W+1) chance, the object or stack will only be deleted if it is not of the same material.)[4]

The unique items, rider corpses, and scrolls of mail never cause system shock,[5][6][7] and are protected from destruction if another object caused it.[8]

Monsters

Monsters have a 1⁄25 chance of dying without leaving a corpse when hit by a wand of polymorph, polymorph spell, or potion of polymorph. The test is done after the tests for magic resistance. Chameleons, doppelgangers, and sandestins are immune, unless the hero has protection from shape changers.[9]

Player

The player is not subject to instant destruction like the other classes of polymorphable things. Instead, when you polymorph randomly, you have a 19 − Con19 chance of experiencing a system shock. If this happens, you lose 1d30 hit points and abuse your constitution. This effect will not occur if you have polymorph control, have lycanthropy, are a vampire or vampire bat, or wear dragon scale mail or dragon scales.[10]

Messages

You feel shuddering vibrations.
A polymorphed object has undergone system shock.
The <monster> shudders.
A polymorphed monster has undergone system shock.
You shudder for a moment.
One of the possible sources of this message is that you have undergone system shock.

References

  1. ↑ obj_shudders in zap.c
  2. ↑ zap.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1353
  3. ↑ create_polymon in zap.c
  4. ↑ polyuse in zap.c
  5. ↑ zap.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1854
  6. ↑ zap.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1338
  7. ↑ obj_resists in zap.c
  8. ↑ zap.c in NetHack 3.6.1, line 1209
  9. ↑ src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 251
  10. ↑ polyself in polyself.c

It may contain text specific to NetHack 3.6.1. Information on this page may be out of date.
